newsitem.title: INDIA: India stocks need direction, Chidambaram holds key.
newsitem.headline: India stocks need direction, Chidambaram holds key.

text.p: India's stock markets will be seeking direction this week, with brokers awaiting tax relief and other measures when Finance Minister P. Chidambaram wraps up a delayed budget debate, brokers said.
The country's bourses have lacked momentum after Chidambaram announced the 1996/97 budget proposals in July which included a minimum tax on profits of high- growth companies.
The 30-share index of the main Bombay Stock Exchange has lost about 280 points or 7.6 percent since the budget announcements on July 22. It closed at 3,508.07 on Friday.

In the first stage of his reply in parliament during a budget debate on Friday, Chidambaram announced a few incentives, including benefits for the mutual fund and debt markets, but brokers were muted in their response.
Traders want the finance minister to dilute the controversial minimum alternate tax on high-growth companies, and offer some excise relief to certain sectors of industry.
"The market will be jerked," said Ramdeo Agarwal, research chief at broking firm Motilal Oswal, if these expectations were not met.
But brokers ruled out any sharp fall in prices.
"The market's not going to collapse," said Uday Kotak, vice chairman at Kotak Mahindra Finance. "Probably it will stay flat."
In parliament on Friday, Chidambaram stressed the need to boost India's capital markets, which include 24 stock exchanges serving more than 20 million investors.
"While speculation is an unavoidable feature of any market, we must impart a certain stability to our markets so that the interests of millions of small investors are protected," Chidambaram said.
The finance minister removed a 30 percent ceiling on investment in debt instruments by foreign institutional investors and said they could float funds specifically dedicated to only debt.

He exempted investments in mutual funds from capital gains tax, raised the ceiling on tax-spared dividend and interest incomes to 15,000 rupees against 13,000 and doubled the limit to 1.0 million rupees for bank advances against shares.
"What's causing some worry is clear signs that the economy is slowing," said Subra Subramanian, director at Hoare Govette (India) Securities Ltd.
"The slowdown will be more in the second half."
Analysts expect corporate profits to grow at 15-20 percent in the first half of the financial year ending March 31, 1997 -- against nearly 30 percent in the year- ago period.
Last week the State Bank of India, the country's largest commercial bank, cut its prime lending rate to 15.5 percent from 16.0 percent to counter a slowing demand for funds.
Several other state-run banks are expected to announce similar cuts in lending rates soon.
Chidambaram's concessions will accelerate the issue of debt instruments, the latest fad for Indian investors seeking safer and better returns, brokers said.
On Monday, the Bombay Stock Exchange will begin trading in debt instruments, while several firms prepare to launch bonds or debentures that offer upwards of 16 percent in annual returns.
